_exec_summary.SummaryText: strengthen our engineering controls to prevent process safety incidents. The Michigan Operations Site also works with the Department of Homeland Security to ensure full compliance with the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard.

ations site hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  The facility has a strict program for informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes, as well as the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Contractors are also required to inform the facility of any hazards they may introduce or encounter while at the site.

Five-year Accident History
The Michigan Operations site has not had any accidents to report as part of the RMP.   

Emergency Response Plan
The Michigan Operations site maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan documents all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The plan is updated as necessary to reflect any pertinent changes within the processes at the facility that would require a modified emergency response.

The facility works with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the facility emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.

Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced in order to ensure that it is functioning properly at all times.  

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Michigan Operations is improving safety by implementing the Prevent. Protect. Respond. (PPR) campaign. PPR focuses on strengthening operational discipline, the identification and mitigation of hazards, and executing appropriate action in response to unplanned events. We are focusing on our procedure use culture to ensure that it remains a strong foundation for process safety. We are identifying and executing strategic projects to

and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training on the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of existing processes are conducted as a regular practice at the Michigan Operations Site.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating & maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup, and that all necessary personnel have been trained prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
The Michigan Operations site conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule and other applicable regulatory requirements are being followed and have been implemented properly.  Audits are conducted using an established schedule for the site.  Corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
The Michigan Operations site promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a serious release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the root causes leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring.  

Employee Participation
The Michigan Operations site operates on the premise that process safety management and accident prevention are a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues, to attend applicable reviews, and to recommend improvements.  Improvements are solicited and implemented as appropriate.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Contractors
On occasion, the Michigan Oper

sses are identified and controlled efficiently.  Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analysis are conducted.  This methodology is supplemented when needed with analyses that may include What if Analysis, Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), Fault Tree Analysis, and Safer Technology and Alternative Analysis (STAA).  A team of qualified personnel perform the studies along with experts in engineering and process operations.  

Operating Procedures
For the purpose of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, the Michigan Operations site maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training
The Michigan Operations site has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity
The Michigan Operations site carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel receive specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at the Michigan Operations site to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment

Vinylidene chloride




Worst and Alternative Case Scenario Selection
Where worst and alternate case scenarios impacted additional receptors, all scenarios were included in the submittal. There are seven (7) worst case toxic and four (4) worst case flammable scenarios in this submittal. There are twenty-four (24) total alternate cases, one (1) of which is a flammable case. 

One item to note is that Rail Waldo Yard 2-methylpropene flammable worst case is included as impacting a population of thirteen (13) due to a Google Earth verification depicting approximately 6 housing units. A population density of 2.2 per housing unit was utilized to arrive at the estimated population. Marplot showed this scenario as having zero population and housing unit impacts. 



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Michigan Operations site has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  Several processes at the facility are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard under 19 CFR 1910.119.  The facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the Michigan Operations Site.


Process Safety Information
The Michigan Operations site maintains detailed records of safety information that, among other things, describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment design associated with all covered processes.  Numerous types of information are available to supplement safety information, including Safety Data Sheets for materials used on site, equipment and engineering design specifications and applicable reactive chemicals testing.

Process Hazard Analysis
The Michigan Operations site conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the proce

additional emergency response expertise.


Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations site operates under two air permits. There is insufficient room in the registration section to list this information for both companies there, so we are providing the information on the second air permit here. The air operating permit for the Dow Silicones Corporation (formerly known as Dow Corning) portion of the stationary source is ROP-A4043-2008.  The DUNS for Dow Silicones Corporation is 005353487.  
The Michigan Operations site's primary activity is chemical manufacturing, including specialty chemicals, silicones and plastics.  There are twenty-six (26) covered processes, forty-two (42) programs and forty-five (45) regulated substances present at the stationary source.  

The regulated substances are listed below.  Seven (7) of the chemicals in the list are not routinely stored on site and/or if present, are present in less than threshold amounts and have been added under the provision of predictive filing.  Predictive filing was done for flammable or toxic chemicals which may be included in waste mixtures received at the facility.

2023 General Executive Summary for The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site.

Revisions to the Plan
Revisions to the July 1st, 2021 plan are being submitted on December 14th, 2023 for the following reasons:

Process Boundary and Maximum Inventory Verification
The 32 Incinerator process has verified its RMP chemical coverage, process boundaries, maximum intended inventories, and updated chemicals that are included predictively. Inventories for logistics processes were updated to allow storage in additional rail sidings and trailer lots on site. The 588 Process was added to the plan due to an ongoing project to store and supply chlorine as a raw material in quantities exceeding threshold. Anticipated arrival of chlorine in the process above threshold quantity is in the first quarter of 2024.  
Addition of Regulated Substances: 
The 32 Incinerator process added fourteen (14) regulated substances as part of the chemical review. 

•	2-Chloropropene
•	Carbon Disulfide
•	Chlorine
•	Chloroform 
•	Crotonaldehyde 
•	Cyclohexylamine 
•	Ethylene Oxide 
•	Formaldehyde 
•	Hydrochloric Acid
•	Isobutane
•	Methyl Formate
•	Methyl Mercaptan
•	Nitric Acid
•	Vinyl Chloride

The 588 Process was added to the RMP with the addition of the chemical below:
•	Chlorine

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Michigan Operations site is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  Appropriate controls are implemented to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release were to occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  The facility also coordinates with the LEPC and City of Midland Fire Department which can provide
